title: Calculating Probability: Average Song Length
question_text:
The length of songs played by a certain radio station is approximately normally distributed with a mean of $210\text{ seconds}$ and a standard deviation of $25\text{ seconds}$.
If DJ turns on the radio just in time to catch the beginning of a new song, what is the probability the song will last between $170$ and $225\text{ seconds}$?
solution:
First, we must turn each of the raw values into $z$-scores. The formula for calculating $z$ is:

$$z=\frac { x-\mu }{ \sigma }$$

...where $x$ is the observed value or value of interest.

$$z=\frac { 170- 210 }{ 25 }=-1.6$$

...and:

$$z=\frac { 225-210 }{ 25 } =0.6$$

So we are looking for $p(-1.6 < z < 0.6)$. The easiest way to find this answer is to use your TI83/84 graphing calculator's normalcdf function. The normalcdf function finds probabilities associated with given $z$-scores. The syntax is: normalcdf(lower bound, upper bound, mean, standard deviation). In this case you would:

Enter 2nd, DISTR
Choose normalcdf
Enter -1.6, 0.6, 0, 1

Enter again and the calculator will return the value of about $0.67$.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect and represents $p(z < -1.6)$.

Choice 'B' is incorrect and represents $p(z > 0.6)$.

Choice 'D' is incorrect and represents $p(z < 0.6)$.

Choice 'E' is incorrect and represents $p(z > -1.6)$.
